sen.j: 小野 篁（おの の たかむら、延暦21年（802年） - 仁寿2年12月22日 (旧暦)（853年2月3日））は、平安時代前期の官人、学者、歌人。
sen.e: ONO no Takamura (802 - February 3, 853) was a bureaucrat, scholar and poet in the early Heian Period
ONO no Takamura (802 - February 3, 853) was a bureaucrat, scholar and poet in the early Heian Period
ONO no Takamura (802 - February 7, 853) was a bureaucrat, scholar and poet in the early Heian period.
sen.cmt: Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更、ピリオド追加February 3→February 7に変更しました。

sen.j: 異名は「野相公」、その反骨精神から「野狂」とも。
sen.e: Also known as 'Yasosho' and 'Yakyo' because of his rebelliousness.

sen.j: 小野篁は遣隋使を務めた小野妹子の子孫で、父は小野岑守。
sen.e: ONO no Takamura was a descendant of ONO no Imoko who served as a member of Japanese official diplomatic delegations sent to China during the Sui dynasty and his father was ONO no Minemori.

sen.j: 孫に三蹟の一人小野道風がいる。
sen.e: One of Sanseki (Three famous calligraphers in Japan) ONO no Tofu was his grandchild.

sen.j: 若年の頃、父に従って陸奥国へ赴き、弓馬をよくしたが、嵯峨天皇の言葉に触れて発奮し大学寮へ入り、官途についた。
sen.e: In his juvenile years, Takamori accompanied his father to the Province of Michinoku where he excelled in archery and horsemanship but was enlightened by the saying of Emperor Saga and joined Daigakuryo whereby starting his bureaucratic career.

In his juvenile years, Takamori accompanied his father to the Province of Michinoku where he excelled in archery and horsemanship but was enlightened by the saying of Emperor Saga and joined Daigakuryo thereby starting his bureaucratic career.

In his juvenile years, Takamori accompanied his father to the Mutsu Province where he excelled in archery and horsemanship but was enlightened by the saying of Emperor Saga and joined Daigakuryo (Bureau of Education under the ritsuryo system) thereby starting his bureaucratic career.
sen.cmt: Province of Michinoku→Mutsu Provinceに修正、Daigakuryoの補足追加

sen.j: 弾正台などを歴任し、法理に明るく『令義解』の編纂にも深く関与している。
sen.e: He worked in various areas including Danjodai (Police Agency) and was knowledgeable about legal matters playing an active role in the compilation of "Ryonogige."

sen.j: 承和 (日本)元年（834年）、遣唐使に任ぜられるが、承和5年（838年）に正使藤原常嗣とのいさかいから、病気と称して職務を拒否したうえ朝廷を批判する詩を作したため、嵯峨上皇の怒りをかい隠岐に流された。
sen.e: He was assigned as a member of the Japanese envoy to China in the Tang Dynasty in 834; but, due to his disagreement with the main ambassador Tsunetsugu FUJIWARA, he refused the assignment by pretending sickness and moreover he wrote a poem to criticize the government which made the Retired Emperor Saga angry so that he was sent to Oki Island.

He was appointed to be a Japanese envoy to China during the Tang Dynasty in 834, but due to a disagreement with Tsunetsugu FUJIWARA, the senior envoy, he turned down the appointment, claiming to be ill; moreover he incurred the anger of Retired Emperor Saga by writing a poem criticizing the government, which resulted in him being sent to Oki Island.

He was appointed to be a Japanese envoy to China during the Tang Dynasty in 834, but due to a disagreement with FUJIWARA no Tsunetsugu, the senior envoy, he turned down the appointment, claiming to be ill; moreover he incurred the anger of Retired Emperor Saga by writing a poem criticizing the government, which resulted in him being sent to Oki Island.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース消去、Tsunetsugu FUJIWARA→FUJIWARA no Tsunetsuguとしました。

sen.j: 1年半の後に許されて帰京。
sen.e: Was exonerated after a year and half and returned to Kyoto.

sen.j: のち従三位参議に至った。
sen.e: Afterwards, he advanced to the post of jusanmisangi (junior third court rank sangi).

sen.j: 『日本文徳天皇実録』に見える薨伝によれば、篁の身長は六尺二寸。
sen.e: According to "A memorial piece"(koden) included in "A true record of Emperor Montoku in Japan"(Nihon Montoku Tenno Jitsuroku), Tofu was 6 feet and 2 inches tall.

sen.cmt: 「ローマ字表記（英訳表記)」の順に修正し、Koden (A memorial piece), "Nihon Montoku Tenno Jitsuroku" (A true record of Emperor Montoku in Japan) としました。"6""2"をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: すなわち180センチを超える巨漢であった。
sen.e: In other words, he was a big man standing over 180 cm.

sen.j: 同じく薨伝によれば、その文才は「天下無双」であったという。
sen.e: Also according to "A memorial piece," his literary talent was 'second to none.'

sen.j: 同じく、金銭に淡白で禄を友人に分け与えていたため貧しかったという。
sen.e: Additionally, since he was indifferent about money giving his pay to his friends, he was always poor.
Additionally, since he was indifferent about money and would give his pay to his friends, he was always poor.

sen.j: 篁は夜ごと井戸を通って地獄に降り、閻魔のもとで裁判の補佐をしていたという。
sen.e: It is said that Takamura descended to hell via a well to assist the King of Hell in his court every night.

sen.j: この井戸は、京都東山の六道珍皇寺にある。
sen.e: This well is located on the grounds of Rkudochinno-ji Temple in Higashiyama, Kyoto and the wooden statues of the King of Hell which is said to be made by Takamura and Takamura himself are enshrined in Enma-do also located on the grounds of that temple.

This well is located on the grounds of Rokudochinno-ji Temple in Higashiyama, Kyoto. The wooden statue of the King of Hell, which is said to be made by Takamura, and Takamura, himself, are enshrined in Enma-do also located on the grounds of that temple.
This well is located on the grounds of Rokudochinno-ji Temple in Higashiyama, Kyoto.

sen.j: また珍皇寺の閻魔堂には、篁作と言われる閻魔大王と篁の木像が並んで安置されている。
sen.e: The wooden statue of the King of Hell, which is said to be made by Takamura, and the wooden statue of Takamura himself, are enshrined in Enma-do Hall also located on the grounds of that temple.
sen.cmt: 「一原文一訳文の例外対処」「木像」は篁にもかかるため、the wooden statue of Takamura himself, とし、Enma-do Hallとしました。

sen.j: 京都市北区にある篁のものと伝えられる墓の隣には、紫式部のものと言われる墓があるが、これは愛欲を描いた咎で地獄に落とされた式部を、篁が閻魔大王にとりなしたという伝説に基づくものである。
sen.e: In Kita Ward, Kyoto City, a tomb which is believed to be that of Takamura and a tomb which is said to be that of Shikibu MURASAKI are placed side by side based on the legend in which that Shikibu was condemned to hell for the sin she committed by describing carnal desires in her book and Takamura interceded with the King of Hell for her.

In Kita Ward, Kyoto City, a tomb which is believed to be that of Takamura and a tomb which is said to be that of Shikibu MURASAKI are placed side by side based on the legend in which Shikibu was condemned to hell for the sin she committed by describing carnal desires in her book and after such condemnation Takamura interceded with the King of Hell for her.

In Kita Ward, Kyoto City, a tomb which is believed to be that of Takamura and a tomb which is said to be that of Murasaki Shikibu are placed side by side based on the legend in which Shikibu was condemned to hell for the sin she committed by describing carnal desires in her book and after such condemnation Takamura interceded with the King of Hell for her.

sen.j: 『今昔物語集』によると、病死して閻魔庁に引据えられたた藤原良相が篁の執成しによって蘇生したという逸話が見える。
sen.e: There is an anecdote in "Tales of Times Now Past (Konjaku Monogatari)" in which, after dying of an illness, FUJIWARA no Yoshimi was taken to the office of the King of Hell but was brought back to life by Takamura's intercession.

There is an anecdote in "Konjaku Monogatarishu" (Tales of Times Now Past) in which, after dying of an illness, FUJIWARA no Yoshimi was taken to the office of the King of Hell; but, was brought back to life by Takamura's intercession.

sen.j: 『宇治拾遺物語』などには、嵯峨天皇のころ、「無悪善」という落書きを「悪（さが（嵯峨のこと））無くば、善けん」（「悪なからば善からん」とも読める。いずれにせよ、「嵯峨天皇がいなければ良いのに」の意。）と読んだ。
sen.e: In literary works such as "Tales of Ujishui (Ujishui Monogatari)," in the era of Emperor Saga, there was a graffiti written by Takamura which said, 'Everything will be fine if there is no evil,' which could be read in a couple of different ways.

In the literary works such as the Tales of Ujishui (Ujishui Monogatari), in the era of Emperor Saga, there was graffiti written by Takamura which said, 'Everything will be fine if there is no evil,' which could be read in a couple of different ways.

In the literary works such as "Ujishui Monogatari" (Tales of Ujishui), in the era of Emperor Saga, there was graffiti written by Takamura which said, 'Everything will be fine if there is no evil,' which could be read in a couple of different ways. Nonetheless, however, it could be interpreted as saying, 'It would be better if Emperor Saga did not exist.'
sen.cmt: the Tales of Ujishui (Ujishui Monogatari)→"Ujishui Monogatari" (Tales of Ujishui)とし、クォーテーションを半角に修正

sen.j: それに立腹した嵯峨天皇の出した「『子』を十二個書いたものを読め」というなぞなぞを、見事に「猫の子の子猫、獅子の子の子獅子」と読み解いてみせ事なきを得た、という逸話も見える。
sen.e: The angry Emperor Saga told Takamura to come up with an answer for a puzzle that repeats a letter meaning 'child' 12 times and Takamura answered, 'Kittens of kittens and cubs of lion cubs,' solving it with flying colors.

sen.j: まだ日本に『白氏文集』が一冊しか渡来していない頃、天皇が戯れに白楽天の詩の一文字を変えて篁に示したところ、篁は改変したその一文字のみを添削して返したという。
sen.e: It is said that, in those days when there was only one copy of "Hakushi Monju" in Japan, when the emperor showed that book to Takamura after changing a character in a poem written by Hakurakuten for fun, Takamura returned the book after correcting the character modified by the emperor.

sen.j: 白楽天は、篁が遣唐使に任ぜられたと聞き、彼に会うのを楽しみしていたという。
